Issues.Title: System fonts at bigger sizes have too narrow line heights
Issues.Body:
<!-- Please provide all of the information requested below. We're a small team and without all of this information it's not possible for us to help and your bug report will be closed. -->

**What version of Tailwind CSS are you using?**

`v3.4.1`

**What build tool (or framework if it abstracts the build tool) are you using?**

CRA, but can reproduce on the Tailwind playground.

**What browser are you using?**

Applies to Chrome, Safari and Firefox.

**What operating system are you using?**

macOS and Windows.

**Reproduction URL**

https://play.tailwindcss.com/BeWzKMu0aN

**Describe your issue**

When using bigger font sizes, the line height when using the default system fonts on macOS and Windows is not enough for descenders. This can lead to unexpected behavior, such as cropped descenders when using `truncate`.

This issue is present on macOS with `text-5xl` and larger, while on Windows, it happens at text sizes `text-3xl` and larger. The reason for this, as far as I can tell, is the difference in the default font on the platforms, where Segoe UI requires a bigger line height than SF NS. In my case, I was able to fix this issue with using `leading-normal` (`line-height: 1.5`), but I assume there is a good reason it's set to `1` on the larger font sizes and the rem sizes for the smaller ones.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "System fonts at bigger sizes have too narrow line heights" (#13293)

Issues.Body: Use Vite [waitForRequestIdle](https://github.com/vitejs/vite/commit/9888843) instead of our custom `setTimeout` back. Issues.Title: Improve `transform`, `transform-cpu` and `transform-gpu` utilities
Issues.Body:
This PR improves the transform utilities by making sure that `transform-cpu` and `transform-gpu` also keep the `skewX` and `skewY` functions into account.

Additionally, `skewX` and `skewY` are dropped from arbitrary values when using `transform-[‚Ä¶]`. This way you always get the arbitrary values as-is without anything else.

We also move the `skewX` and `skewY` functions into the `--tw-skew-x` and `--tw-skew-y` variables themselves, because otherwise it could happen that the variable is not defined and then we use `skewX(--variable-that-is-not-defined)`.

By doing that, we also updated the `transform-cpu` and `transform-gpu` to use the `--tw-skew-x` and `--tw-skew-y` variables that already include the `skewX` and `skewY` functions. We also use the `var(--tw-skew-x,)` value (with the dangling comma) to ensure the full `transform` property is valid. 

Notice how the `,` is important:

https://github.com/tailwindlabs/tailwindcss/assets/1834413/01895880-427b-407f-9e11-6765f6ca8dbf

Issues.Title: Improve bare values and theme key fallbacks
Issues.Body:
This PR improves some of the utilities where we read from the theme but also have support for bare values. Some of the combinations don't really make sense.

For example, `translate-x-48` would pick `48` from the theme, which maps to `12rem`, but `translate-x-50` doesn't exist in the theme, so it would just use bare values and in this case it would map to `50%`.

Issues.Title: Remove bare value handling for perspective utilities
Issues.Body:
This PR removes bare value handling from the perspective utilities, so that utilities like `perspective-300` will no longer generate declarations like `perspective: 300px`.

Generally we support bare values as a way to avoid putting things into the default theme, and since the perspective utilities already have a named scale in the theme I don't think it makes sense to support bare values. Bare values should be thought of as real API that we would include in the IntelliSense completions list when someone is typing a utility, and I don't think we want to include any numeric values in that list for `perspective` üëç
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed or merged PR "Remove bare value handling for perspective utilities" (#13288)

Issues.Title: allow for network imports
Issues.Body:
<!--

üëã Hey, thanks for your interest in contributing to Tailwind!

It's never a fun experience to have your pull request declined after investing a lot of time and effort into a new feature. This includes things like adding new utilities, creating new at-rules, or adding new component examples to the documentation.

https://github.com/tailwindcss/tailwindcss/blob/master/.github/CONTRIBUTING.md

-->
This PR adds support for url imports in the binary executable. This allows for tailwind plugins to be imported from the internet if you aren't using node.js. e.g
```js
import daisyui from "https://esm.sh/daisyui"
module.exports = {
  content: ['./templates/**/*.html'],
  theme: {
    extend: {},
  },
  plugins: [
    require('@tailwindcss/forms'),
    require('@tailwindcss/typography'),
    daisyui
  ],
}
```

Issues.Title: 3D transform utilities
Issues.Body:
Based on #10982 by @brandonmcconnell. Add 3D transform utilities. All are applied to specific CSS properties rather than as `transform` functions. | Utility | CSS Property | CSS Value | |--------|--------|--------| | `rotate` | `rotate` | arbitrary values can be used to define an axis of rotation
(e.g. `rotate_[1_2_3_45deg]`) | | `rotate-x` | `rotate` | same as `rotate`, applied in the x-dimension; see note below | | `rotate-y` | `rotate` | same as `rotate`, applied in the y-dimension; see note below | | `scale` | `scale` | arbitrary values are now supported
(e.g. `scale-[2_1.5_3]`, `scale-[var(--custom-scale)]`) | | `scale-z` | `scale` | same as `scale`, applied only to the z-dimension | | `scale-3d` | `scale` | applies `scale` across the z-dimension
(e.g. `scale-50 scale-3d` is equivalent to `scale-50 scale-z-50`) | | `translate-z` | `translate` | same as `translate`, applied only to the z-dimension | | `translate-3d` | `translate` | applies `translate` across the z-dimension
(e.g. `translate-full translate-3d` is equivalent to `translate-full translate-z-full`) | | `perspective` | `perspective` | `dramatic` (`100px`), `near` (`300px`), `normal` (`500px`), `midrange` (`800px`), `distant` (`1200px`), or arbitrary (e.g. `perspective-[42px]`) | | `perspective-origin` | `perspective-origin` | same as `origin` (`transform-origin`) | | `transform` | `transform` | arbitrary values (e.g. `transform-[rotateX(45deg)_rotateY(-90deg)]`) are now supported | | `transform-flat` | `transform-style` | `flat` | | `transform-3d` | `transform-style` | `preserve-3d` | | `transform-content` | `transform-box` | `content-box` | | `transform-border` | `transform-box` | `border-box` | | `transform-fill` | `transform-box` | `fill-box` | | `transform-stroke` | `transform-box` | `stroke-box` | | `transform-view` | `transform-box` | `view-box` | | `backface-visible` | `backface-visibility` | `visible` | | `backface-hidden` | `backface-visibility` | `hidden` | *Note on `rotate`, `rotate-x`, and `rotate-y`*: Rotations are applied using the `rotate` property, which supports a single angle of rotation along with an axis of rotation. `rotate` defaults to the z-dimension and can specify other dimensions (including a vector) using an arbitrary value. Applying multiple rotations in a sequence is order-dependent and can be done using an arbitrary `transform` value (e.g. `transform-[rotateX(45deg)_rotateY(-90deg)]`). Care has been taken to only apply transformations in the z-dimension when the relevant utilities are used. This should avoid triggering GPU rendering except when needed.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed or merged PR "3D transform utilities" (#13248)

Issues.Title: Parse candidates in `.svelte` files with `class:abc="condition"` syntax
Issues.Body:
This PR introduces backwards compatibility for the `class:` syntax in Svelte files.

In Svelte there is a convention where you can use `<div class:px-4="condition" />` which allows you to apply the `px-4` class conditionally based on a condition. This also means that we extract `class:px-4` as a utility where `class` is a variant and `px-4` is the utility.

This is obviously incorrect, to solve this we can ignore the `class:` part before parsing the whole file.

This is also what we do in v3.

In a perfect world, we have more specific parsers depending on the file type before using the generic parser we use now. But that's a bigger project on its own way beyond the scope of this PR.

Fixes: #13263

Issues.Title: [v4] `transform` utilities not working in Firefox due to no support for `@property`
Issues.Body:
**What version of Tailwind CSS are you using?** v4.0.0-alpha.9 **What build tool (or framework if it abstracts the build tool) are you using?** @tailwindcss/postcss 4.0.0-alpha.9, Next.js 14.1.3 **What version of Node.js are you using?** v20.11.0 **What browser are you using?** Firefox v123.0.1 (64 bit) **What operating system are you using?** macOS **Reproduction URL** Clone the NextJS repo at https://github.com/zoomoid/tailwindcss-4-experiments and run the project in `missing-transform-defaults`. **Describe your issue** Firefox currently only has support for `@property` in nightly builds and not at all for Firefox for Android. The CSS variables used in `transform`, `translate` and so forth are partially undefined in Firefox, rendering the entire rule without effect. In the example above, the `

` should be translated by 2rem to the right, using `transform translate-x-8`. This works in Chrome and Safari as previously in < 4.0.0, because `translate-x-*` expands to two rules, one for setting `--tw-translate-x` and one for rendering ```css transform: translate(var(--tw-translate-x),var(--tw-translate-y)) rotate(var(--tw-rotate)) skewX(var(--tw-skew-x)) skewY(var(--tw-skew-y)) scaleX(var(--tw-scale-x)) scaleY(var(--tw-scale-y)); ``` where the rest of the variables are defaulted from the preflight settings. In v4, these are set via CSS's `@property` rules with appropriate defaults, but those at-rules are not yet supported in mainline Firefox. `translate-x-*` is also expanded into a singular rule, e.g., ```css .translate-x-8 { --tw-translate-x: 3rem; translate: var(--tw-translate-x) var(--tw-translate-y); } ``` where the undefinedness of --tw-translate-y breaks the property's effect. You can quickly fix this by adding ```css --tw-translate-x: 0; --tw-translate-y: 0; --tw-rotate: 0; --tw-skew-x: 0; --tw-skew-y: 0; --tw-scale-x: 1; --tw-scale-y: 1; ``` to your `@theme` block to default them at the root.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "[v4] `transform` utilities not working in Firefox due to no support for `@property`" (#13268)

Issues.Title: [v4] `max-w-screen-*` utilities are not provided by default
Issues.Body:
**What version of Tailwind CSS are you using?**

v4.0.0-alpha.9

**What build tool (or framework if it abstracts the build tool) are you using?**

@tailwindcss/postcss 4.0.0-alpha.9, Next.js 14.1.3

**What version of Node.js are you using?**

v20.11.0

**What browser are you using?**

Chrome, Firefox, Safari

**What operating system are you using?**

macOS

**Reproduction URL**

Clone the NextJS repo at <https://github.com/zoomoid/tailwindcss-4-experiments> and run the project in `missing-screen-widths`. Observe that the first `<div>` using `max-w-md` works as intended, whereas the second `<div>` using `max-w-screen-md` (which worked fine in < 4.0.0) has no utility for its max-width.

**Describe your issue**

`max-w-screen-*` utilities for using the breakpoints as max-widths are currently not included in the set of widths in `packages/tailwindcss/theme.css`. Afaik those aren't noted as being deprecated.

You can add them via the `@theme` directive by adding 

```css
--width-screen-sm: var(--breakpoint-sm);
--width-screen-md: var(--breakpoint-md);
--width-screen-lg: var(--breakpoint-lg);
--width-screen-xl: var(--breakpoint-xl);
--width-screen-2xl: var(--breakpoint-2xl);
```

or for any additional breakpoints created by yourself following the same schema. Afterwards, `max-w-screen-*` will work as expected again.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "[v4] `max-w-screen-*` utilities are not provided by default" (#13267)

Issues.Title: Inline `@import` rules in `tailwindcss/index.css` at publish time for better performance
Issues.Body:
This way none of the tools using `@import "tailwindcss";` have to resolve imports at "runtime" because it will already be inlined when it's published.

This does increase the bundle size of the `tailwindcss` package, but it's still going to be a very small package.

Issues.Title: Move `optimizeCss` to the packages where it's used
Issues.Body:
Right now `optimizeCss` lives in `tailwindcss`, but it is not used within the `tailwindcss` package itself (apart from tests).

It's currently only used in our packages that users interact with directly:

- `@tailwindcss/cli`
- `@tailwindcss/postcss`
- `@tailwindcss/vite`

This PR moves `optimizeCss` to the packages listed above, the `lightningcss` dependency is also moved to those packages.

This means that `tailwindcss` itself is now dependency free.
